trans-unit.source: Introduction to Apache Storm on HDInsight: Real-time analytics for Hadoop
trans-unit.target: Introduction to Apache Storm on HDInsight: Real-time analytics for Hadoop

trans-unit.source: Apache Storm on HDInsight allows you to create distributed, real-time analytics solutions in the Azure environment by using [Apache Hadoop](http://hadoop.apache.org).
trans-unit.target: Apache Storm on HDInsight allows you to create distributed, real-time analytics solutions in the Azure environment by using [Apache Hadoop](http://hadoop.apache.org).

trans-unit.source: What is Apache Storm?
trans-unit.target: What is Apache Storm?

trans-unit.source: Apache Storm is a distributed, fault-tolerant, open-source computation system that allows you to process data in real-time with Hadoop.
trans-unit.target: Apache Storm is a distributed, fault-tolerant, open-source computation system that allows you to process data in real-time with Hadoop.

trans-unit.source: Storm solutions can also provide guaranteed processing of data, with the ability to replay data that was not successfully processed the first time.
trans-unit.target: Storm solutions can also provide guaranteed processing of data, with the ability to replay data that was not successfully processed the first time.

trans-unit.source: Reliability
trans-unit.target: Reliability

trans-unit.source: Apache Storm always guarantees that each incoming message will be fully processed, even when the data analysis is spread over hundreds of nodes.
trans-unit.target: Apache Storm always guarantees that each incoming message will be fully processed, even when the data analysis is spread over hundreds of nodes.

trans-unit.source: The **Nimbus node** provides similar functionality to the Hadoop JobTracker, and it assigns tasks to other nodes in the cluster through **Zookeeper**.
trans-unit.target: The **Nimbus node** provides similar functionality to the Hadoop JobTracker, and it assigns tasks to other nodes in the cluster through **Zookeeper**.

trans-unit.source: Zookeeper nodes provide coordination for the cluster and facilitate communication between Nimbus and the **Supervisor** process on the worker nodes.
trans-unit.target: Zookeeper nodes provide coordination for the cluster and facilitate communication between Nimbus and the **Supervisor** process on the worker nodes.

trans-unit.source: If one processing node goes down, the Nimbus node is informed, and it assigns the task and associated data to another node.
trans-unit.target: If one processing node goes down, the Nimbus node is informed, and it assigns the task and associated data to another node.

trans-unit.source: The default configuration for Apache Storm is to have only one Nimbus node.
trans-unit.target: The default configuration for Apache Storm is to have only one Nimbus node.

trans-unit.source: Storm on HDInsight runs two Nimbus nodes.
trans-unit.target: Storm on HDInsight runs two Nimbus nodes.

trans-unit.source: If the primary node fails, the HDInsight cluster will switch to the secondary node while the primary node is recovered.
trans-unit.target: If the primary node fails, the HDInsight cluster will switch to the secondary node while the primary node is recovered.

trans-unit.source: How is data in HDInsight Storm processed?
trans-unit.target: How is data in HDInsight Storm processed?

trans-unit.source: Apache Storm runs **topologies** instead of the MapReduce jobs that you may be familiar with in HDInsight or Hadoop.
trans-unit.target: Apache Storm runs **topologies** instead of the MapReduce jobs that you may be familiar with in HDInsight or Hadoop.

trans-unit.source: A Storm on HDInsight cluster contains two types of nodes: head nodes that run **Nimbus** and worker nodes that run **Supervisor**.
trans-unit.target: A Storm on HDInsight cluster contains two types of nodes: head nodes that run **Nimbus** and worker nodes that run **Supervisor**.

trans-unit.source: **Nimbus**: Similar to the JobTracker in Hadoop, it is responsible for distributing code throughout the cluster, assigning tasks to virtual machines, and monitoring for failure.
trans-unit.target: **Nimbus**: Similar to the JobTracker in Hadoop, it is responsible for distributing code throughout the cluster, assigning tasks to virtual machines, and monitoring for failure.

trans-unit.source: HDInsight provides two Nimbus nodes, so there is no single point of failure for Storm on HDInsight
trans-unit.target: HDInsight provides two Nimbus nodes, so there is no single point of failure for Storm on HDInsight

trans-unit.source: **Supervisor**: The supervisor for each worker node is responsible for starting and stopping **worker processes** on the node.
trans-unit.target: **Supervisor**: The supervisor for each worker node is responsible for starting and stopping **worker processes** on the node.

trans-unit.source: **Worker process**: Runs a subset of a **topology**.
trans-unit.target: **Worker process**: Runs a subset of a **topology**.

trans-unit.source: A running topology is distributed across many worker processes throughout the cluster.
trans-unit.target: A running topology is distributed across many worker processes throughout the cluster.

trans-unit.source: **Topology**: Defines a graph of computation that processes **streams** of data.
trans-unit.target: **Topology**: Defines a graph of computation that processes **streams** of data.

trans-unit.source: Unlike MapReduce jobs, topologies run until you stop them.
trans-unit.target: Unlike MapReduce jobs, topologies run until you stop them.

trans-unit.source: **Stream**: An unbound collection of **tuples**.
trans-unit.target: **Stream**: An unbound collection of **tuples**.

trans-unit.source: Streams are produced by **spouts** and **bolts**, and they are consumed by **bolts**.
trans-unit.target: Streams are produced by **spouts** and **bolts**, and they are consumed by **bolts**.

trans-unit.source: **Tuple**: A named list of dynamically typed values.
trans-unit.target: **Tuple**: A named list of dynamically typed values.

trans-unit.source: **Spout**: Consumes data from a data source and emits one or more **streams**.
trans-unit.target: **Spout**: Consumes data from a data source and emits one or more **streams**.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] In many cases, data is read from a queue, such as Kafka, Azure Service Bus queues, or Event hubs.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] In many cases, data is read from a queue, such as Kafka, Azure Service Bus queues, or Event hubs.

trans-unit.source: The queue ensures that data is persisted if there is an outage.
trans-unit.target: The queue ensures that data is persisted if there is an outage.

trans-unit.source: **Bolt**: Consumes **streams**, performs processing on **tuples**, and may emit **streams**.
trans-unit.target: **Bolt**: Consumes **streams**, performs processing on **tuples**, and may emit **streams**.

trans-unit.source: Bolts are also responsible for writing data to external storage, such as a queue, HDInsight, HBase, a blob, or other data store.
trans-unit.target: Bolts are also responsible for writing data to external storage, such as a queue, HDInsight, HBase, a blob, or other data store.

trans-unit.source: **Apache Thrift**: A software framework for scalable cross-language service development.
trans-unit.target: **Apache Thrift**: A software framework for scalable cross-language service development.

trans-unit.source: It allows you to build services that work between C++, Java, Python, PHP, Ruby, Erlang, Perl, Haskell, C#, Cocoa, JavaScript, Node.js, Smalltalk, and other languages.
trans-unit.target: It allows you to build services that work between C++, Java, Python, PHP, Ruby, Erlang, Perl, Haskell, C#, Cocoa, JavaScript, Node.js, Smalltalk, and other languages.

trans-unit.source: **Nimbus** is a Thrift service, and a **topology** is a Thrift definition, so it is possible to develop topologies using a variety of programming languages.
trans-unit.target: **Nimbus** is a Thrift service, and a **topology** is a Thrift definition, so it is possible to develop topologies using a variety of programming languages.

trans-unit.source: Java
trans-unit.target: Java

trans-unit.source: Most Java examples you encounter will be plain Java or Trident.
trans-unit.target: Most Java examples you encounter will be plain Java or Trident.

trans-unit.source: Trident is a high-level abstraction that makes it easier to do things such as joins, aggregations, grouping, and filtering.
trans-unit.target: Trident is a high-level abstraction that makes it easier to do things such as joins, aggregations, grouping, and filtering.

trans-unit.source: However, Trident acts on batches of tuples, whereas a raw Java solution processes a stream one tuple at a time.
trans-unit.target: However, Trident acts on batches of tuples, whereas a raw Java solution processes a stream one tuple at a time.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Trident, see the [Trident tutorial](https://storm.incubator.apache.org/documentation/Trident-tutorial.html) at apache.org.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Trident, see the [Trident tutorial](https://storm.incubator.apache.org/documentation/Trident-tutorial.html) at apache.org.

trans-unit.target: For examples of raw Java and Trident topologies, see the **%storm_home%\contrib\storm-starter** directory on your HDInsight Storm cluster.

trans-unit.source: What are some common development patterns?
trans-unit.target: What are some common development patterns?

trans-unit.source: Guaranteed message processing
trans-unit.target: Guaranteed message processing

trans-unit.source: Storm can provide different levels of guaranteed message processing.
trans-unit.target: Storm can provide different levels of guaranteed message processing.

trans-unit.source: For example, a basic Storm application can guarantee at-least-once processing, and Trident can guarantee exactly-once processing.
trans-unit.target: For example, a basic Storm application can guarantee at-least-once processing, and Trident can guarantee exactly-once processing.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Guarantees on data processing](https://storm.apache.org/about/guarantees-data-processing.html) at apache.org.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Guarantees on data processing](https://storm.apache.org/about/guarantees-data-processing.html) at apache.org.

trans-unit.source: IBasicBolt
trans-unit.target: IBasicBolt

trans-unit.source: The pattern of reading an input tuple, emitting zero or more tuples, and then acking the input tuple immediately at the end of the execute method is very common, and Storm provides the [IBasicBolt](https://storm.apache.org/apidocs/backtype/storm/topology/IBasicBolt.html) interface to automate this pattern.
trans-unit.target: The pattern of reading an input tuple, emitting zero or more tuples, and then acking the input tuple immediately at the end of the execute method is very common, and Storm provides the [IBasicBolt](https://storm.apache.org/apidocs/backtype/storm/topology/IBasicBolt.html) interface to automate this pattern.

trans-unit.source: Joins
trans-unit.target: Joins

trans-unit.source: Joining two streams of data will vary between applications.
trans-unit.target: Joining two streams of data will vary between applications.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could join each tuple from multiple streams into one new stream, or you could join only batches of tuples for a specific window.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could join each tuple from multiple streams into one new stream, or you could join only batches of tuples for a specific window.

trans-unit.source: Either way, joining can be accomplished by using [fieldsGrouping](http://javadox.com/org.apache.storm/storm-core/0.9.1-incubating/backtype/storm/topology/InputDeclarer.html#fieldsGrouping%28java.lang.String,%20backtype.storm.tuple.Fields%29), which is a way of defining how tuples are routed to bolts.
trans-unit.target: Either way, joining can be accomplished by using [fieldsGrouping](http://javadox.com/org.apache.storm/storm-core/0.9.1-incubating/backtype/storm/topology/InputDeclarer.html#fieldsGrouping%28java.lang.String,%20backtype.storm.tuple.Fields%29), which is a way of defining how tuples are routed to bolts.

trans-unit.source: In the following Java example, fieldsGrouping is used to route tuples that originate from components "1", "2", and "3" to the **MyJoiner** bolt.
trans-unit.target: In the following Java example, fieldsGrouping is used to route tuples that originate from components "1", "2", and "3" to the **MyJoiner** bolt.

trans-unit.source: Batching
trans-unit.target: Batching

trans-unit.source: Batching can be accomplished several ways.
trans-unit.target: Batching can be accomplished several ways.

trans-unit.source: With a basic Storm Java topology, you might use simple counter to batch X number of tuples before emitting them, or use an internal timing mechanism known as a "tick tuple" to emit a batch every X seconds.
trans-unit.target: With a basic Storm Java topology, you might use simple counter to batch X number of tuples before emitting them, or use an internal timing mechanism known as a "tick tuple" to emit a batch every X seconds.

trans-unit.source: For an example of using tick tuples, see [Analyzing sensor data with Storm and HBase on HDInsight](hdinsight-storm-sensor-data-analysis.md).
trans-unit.target: For an example of using tick tuples, see [Analyzing sensor data with Storm and HBase on HDInsight](hdinsight-storm-sensor-data-analysis.md).

trans-unit.source: If you are using Trident, it is based on processing batches of tuples.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Trident, it is based on processing batches of tuples.

trans-unit.source: Caching
trans-unit.target: Caching

trans-unit.source: In-memory caching is often used as a mechanism for speeding up processing because it keeps frequently used assets in memory.
trans-unit.target: In-memory caching is often used as a mechanism for speeding up processing because it keeps frequently used assets in memory.

trans-unit.source: Because a topology is distributed across multiple nodes, and multiple processes within each node, you should consider using [fieldsGrouping](http://javadox.com/org.apache.storm/storm-core/0.9.1-incubating/backtype/storm/topology/InputDeclarer.html#fieldsGrouping%28java.lang.String,%20backtype.storm.tuple.Fields%29) to ensure that tuples containing the fields that are used for cache lookup are always routed to the same process.
trans-unit.target: Because a topology is distributed across multiple nodes, and multiple processes within each node, you should consider using [fieldsGrouping](http://javadox.com/org.apache.storm/storm-core/0.9.1-incubating/backtype/storm/topology/InputDeclarer.html#fieldsGrouping%28java.lang.String,%20backtype.storm.tuple.Fields%29) to ensure that tuples containing the fields that are used for cache lookup are always routed to the same process.

trans-unit.source: This avoids duplication of cache entries across processes.
trans-unit.target: This avoids duplication of cache entries across processes.

trans-unit.source: Streaming top N
trans-unit.target: Streaming top N

trans-unit.source: When your topology depends on calculating a "top N" value, such as the top 5 trends on Twitter, you should calculate the top N value in parallel and then merge the output from those calculations into a global value.
trans-unit.target: When your topology depends on calculating a "top N" value, such as the top 5 trends on Twitter, you should calculate the top N value in parallel and then merge the output from those calculations into a global value.

trans-unit.source: This can be done by using [fieldsGrouping](http://javadox.com/org.apache.storm/storm-core/0.9.1-incubating/backtype/storm/topology/InputDeclarer.html#fieldsGrouping%28java.lang.String,%20backtype.storm.tuple.Fields%29) to route by field to the parallel bolts (which partitions the data by field value), and then route to a bolt that globally determines the top N value.
trans-unit.target: This can be done by using [fieldsGrouping](http://javadox.com/org.apache.storm/storm-core/0.9.1-incubating/backtype/storm/topology/InputDeclarer.html#fieldsGrouping%28java.lang.String,%20backtype.storm.tuple.Fields%29) to route by field to the parallel bolts (which partitions the data by field value), and then route to a bolt that globally determines the top N value.

trans-unit.source: For an example of this, see the [RollingTopWords](https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm-starter/blob/master/src/jvm/storm/starter/RollingTopWords.java) example.
trans-unit.target: For an example of this, see the [RollingTopWords](https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm-starter/blob/master/src/jvm/storm/starter/RollingTopWords.java) example.
